(Bottom) A view of the “zigzag” chain of [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(PyBIm)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>].</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>

<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Four silver (I) coordination polymers were prepared by the reactions of PyBIm and various silver(I) salts under different conditions. The results show that the anions play important roles in the coordination sphere of the silver(I) atoms as well as the crystal packing of the coordination polymers.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Four silver (I) coordination polymers were prepared by the reactions of PyBIm and various silver(I) salts under different conditions. The results show that the anions play important roles in the coordination sphere of the silver(I) atoms as well as the crystal packing of the coordination polymers.

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Four new silver(I) complexes constructed with 2-(4-pyridyl)benzimidazole, namely, [Ag(PyBIm)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Ag(PyBIm)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(PyBIm)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(SiF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and [Ag(PyBIm)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(HBDC)] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) (PyBIm<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2-(4-pyridyl)benzimidazole, BDC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,3-benzenedicarboxylate) have been synthesized and characterized by X-ray crystallography. All the silver(I) atoms in complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are bridged by the different PyBIm ligands via N<ce:inf loc="post">Py</ce:inf> and N<ce:inf loc="post">BIm</ce:inf> into one-dimensional “zigzag” chains. The anions do not coordinate to the silver(I) atoms and only act as counter ions in complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Due to the anions, different hydrogen bonding systems are found in those three compounds, resulting in the different crystal packing. Through hydrogen bonding interactions, the structures of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> display a double layer, a three-dimensional framework and a novel double chain, respectively. In complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, the HBDC<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions act not only as a counter ion but also as bridging ligands, which lead the “zigzag” [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(PyBIm)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> chain into a two-dimensional undulating sheet. The sheets are connected through hydrogen-bonding as well as π–π interactions into a three-dimensional framework. The thermal stabilities of the four complexes and anion exchange properties of complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were also studied.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Four new silver(I) complexes constructed with 2-(4-pyridyl)benzimidazole, namely, [Ag(PyBIm)⋅H2O]⋅NO3 (1), [Ag(PyBIm)⋅H2O]⋅ClO4 (2), [Ag2(PyBIm)2]⋅(SiF6)⋅2H2O (3) and [Ag(PyBIm)⋅(HBDC)] (4) (PyBIm=2-(4-pyridyl)benzimidazole, BDC=1,3-benzenedicarboxylate) have been synthesized and characterized by X-ray crystallography. All the silver(I) atoms in complexes 1-4 are bridged by the different PyBIm ligands via NPy and NBIm into one-dimensional "zigzag" chains. The anions do not coordinate to the silver(I) atoms and only act as counter ions in complexes 1-3. Due to the anions, different hydrogen bonding systems are found in those three compounds, resulting in the different crystal packing. Through hydrogen bonding interactions, the structures of complexes 1-3 display a double layer, a three-dimensional framework and a novel double chain, respectively. In complex 4, the HBDC- anions act not only as a counter ion but also as bridging ligands, which lead the "zigzag" [Ag2(PyBIm)2]∞ chain into a two-dimensional undulating sheet. The sheets are connected through hydrogen-bonding as well as π-π interactions into a three-dimensional framework. The thermal stabilities of the four complexes and anion exchange properties of complexes 2 and 3 were also studied.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In inorganic–organic supramolecular architectures derived from building blocks that are linked by coordinate covalent bonds or hydrogen bonds, π–π interactions constitute an active field that impinges on the synthesis of interesting topological structures and potential function materials . However, the influence on coordination polymers is not well understood, although the self-assembly of those architectures has been documented to be heavily influence by various factors such as functionality and denticity of the ligands , molar ratio of the reagents, the pH values of the solution , and steric requirements of the counter ions . The exploration of synthetic strategies and routines is a long-term challenge, and a great deal of work is required to extend the knowledge of relevant structural types and establish proper synthetic strategies leading to desirable supramolecular species.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In inorganic-organic supramolecular architectures derived from building blocks that are linked by coordinate covalent bonds or hydrogen bonds, π-π interactions constitute an active field that impinges on the synthesis of interesting topological structures and potential function materials . However, the influence on coordination polymers is not well understood, although the self-assembly of those architectures has been documented to be heavily influence by various factors such as functionality and denticity of the ligands , molar ratio of the reagents, the pH values of the solution , and steric requirements of the counter ions . The exploration of synthetic strategies and routines is a long-term challenge, and a great deal of work is required to extend the knowledge of relevant structural types and establish proper synthetic strategies leading to desirable supramolecular species.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Recently, we have focused on the research of silver(I) complexes based on 2-(4-pyridyl)benzimidazole . Compared with the complexes based on 2,4′-bipyridine , the non-coordinating N–H groups of the benzimidazolyl form strong hydrogen-bonding interactions with lattice water and sulfate groups, leading to a wholly different crystal packing. The results also demonstrate that the different pH values result in the sulfate existing in different modes, bringing about crystal structures that are greatly different from each other.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Recently, we have focused on the research of silver(I) complexes based on 2-(4-pyridyl)benzimidazole . Compared with the complexes based on 2,4'-bipyridine , the non-coordinating N-H groups of the benzimidazolyl form strong hydrogen-bonding interactions with lattice water and sulfate groups, leading to a wholly different crystal packing. The results also demonstrate that the different pH values result in the sulfate existing in different modes, bringing about crystal structures that are greatly different from each other.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In this paper, we report four new silver(I) complexes based on PyBIm, namely, [Ag(PyBIm)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Ag(PyBIm)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(PyBIm)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(SiF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and [Ag(PyBIm)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(HBDC)] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>). The Ag(I) atoms are three coordinated in complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> but two and four coordinated in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, respectively. All the silver(I) atoms of the complexes are bridged by PyBIm via N<ce:inf loc="post">Py</ce:inf> and N<ce:inf loc="post">BIm</ce:inf> into “zigzag” chains. The counter ions have a great effect on the hydrogen bonding systems and coordination spheres, leading to great differences in the crystal packing. Through the hydrogen bonding interactions, the structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> display a double-layer, a three-dimensional framework and a novel double-chain, respectively. As for complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, the bridging HBDC<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions connect the [Ag(PyBIm)]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> zigzag chain into a two-dimensional coordinate sheet. The counter ions effects and hydrogen-bonding interactions on the polymeric structures represent a new contribution to this active area of study.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this paper, we report four new silver(I) complexes based on PyBIm, namely, [Ag(PyBIm)⋅H2O]⋅NO3 (1), [Ag(PyBIm)⋅H2O]⋅ClO4 (2), [Ag2(PyBIm)2]⋅(SiF6)⋅2H2O (3) and [Ag(PyBIm)⋅(HBDC)] (4). The Ag(I) atoms are three coordinated in complexes 1 and 2 but two and four coordinated in 3 and 4, respectively. All the silver(I) atoms of the complexes are bridged by PyBIm via NPy and NBIm into "zigzag" chains. The counter ions have a great effect on the hydrogen bonding systems and coordination spheres, leading to great differences in the crystal packing. Through the hydrogen bonding interactions, the structures of 1-3 display a double-layer, a three-dimensional framework and a novel double-chain, respectively. As for complex 4, the bridging HBDC- anions connect the [Ag(PyBIm)]∞ zigzag chain into a two-dimensional coordinate sheet. The counter ions effects and hydrogen-bonding interactions on the polymeric structures represent a new contribution to this active area of study.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Materials and methods</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The ligand 2-(4-pyridyl)benzimidazole (PyBIm) was synthesized according to the procedure reported by Fieselman . Other reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses were carried out on an EA1110 CHNS-0 CE element analyzer and the IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded at a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer in the range 400-4000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed with a Netzsch STA-499C thermoanalyzer under N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (30–800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C range) at a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min. X-ray powder diffractions (XRPD) were performed on a Bruker D8 Advanced diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.5418<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at room temperature.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and methods

The ligand 2-(4-pyridyl)benzimidazole (PyBIm) was synthesized according to the procedure reported by Fieselman . Other reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses were carried out on an EA1110 CHNS-0 CE element analyzer and the IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded at a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer in the range 400-4000cm-1. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed with a Netzsch STA-499C thermoanalyzer under N2 (30-800°C range) at a heating rate of 10°C/min. X-ray powder diffractions (XRPD) were performed on a Bruker D8 Advanced diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.5418Å) at room temperature.

<ce:para view="all">
<ce:italic>Safety notes.</ce:italic> Caution! Perchlorate salts of metal complexes with organic ligands are potentially explosive. Only a small amount of material should be prepared, and it should be handled with great care.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Safety notes. Caution! Perchlorate salts of metal complexes with organic ligands are potentially explosive. Only a small amount of material should be prepared, and it should be handled with great care.

elements.content:

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Suitable single crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. The diffraction data were collected on a Siemens Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at 293<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the <ce:small-caps>sadabs</ce:small-caps> program . The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> by using the <ce:small-caps>shelxtl</ce:small-caps>-97 program package . Attempts to locate the hydrogen atoms of water in complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> failed; the other hydrogen atoms on carbon and nitrogen atoms were generated geometrically. The crystallography details for the structure determination of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are presented in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Suitable single crystals of 1-4 were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. The diffraction data were collected on a Siemens Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å) at 293K. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the sadabs program . The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 by using the shelxtl-97 program package . Attempts to locate the hydrogen atoms of water in complex 3 failed; the other hydrogen atoms on carbon and nitrogen atoms were generated geometrically. The crystallography details for the structure determination of complexes 1-4 are presented in  . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in  .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Result and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Syntheses and general characterization</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can also be obtained by hydrothermal methods, but the crystals obtained were not suitable for X-ray diffraction. As for complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, it can be obtained by hydrothermal methods (the reaction temperature might be better less than 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for security considerations) with the production of crystals of excellent quality that are suitable for X-ray diffraction, but for safety considerations, this is not worthy of recommendation. As for complexes <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, attempts to get crystals under solution conditions failed. The purities of the four complexes were also identified by XRPD (see ).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Result and discussion

Syntheses and general characterization

Complex 1 can also be obtained by hydrothermal methods, but the crystals obtained were not suitable for X-ray diffraction. As for complex 2, it can be obtained by hydrothermal methods (the reaction temperature might be better less than 120°C for security considerations) with the production of crystals of excellent quality that are suitable for X-ray diffraction, but for safety considerations, this is not worthy of recommendation. As for complexes 3 and 4, attempts to get crystals under solution conditions failed. The purities of the four complexes were also identified by XRPD (see ).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The HBDC<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions bridge the [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(PyBIm)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> chain into a two-dimensional sheet in complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, the protonated carboxylate groups greatly contribute to the crystal packing. Attempts to get a crystal bridged by BDC<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> rather than HBDC<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions failed, the products are only amorphous, and could not be identified easily.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The HBDC- anions bridge the [Ag2(PyBIm)2]∞ chain into a two-dimensional sheet in complex 4, the protonated carboxylate groups greatly contribute to the crystal packing. Attempts to get a crystal bridged by BDC2- rather than HBDC- anions failed, the products are only amorphous, and could not be identified easily.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The TGA diagrams show complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> have similar thermal stabilities and behaviors in the range of 50–220<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits loss of one lattice water between 65 and 216<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (4.91% weight loss observed; 4.70% calculated), complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits loss of the water molecules between 48 and 147<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (4.05% weight loss observed; 4.28% calculated), while complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibits loss of two water molecules between 66 and 195<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (4.53% weight loss observed; 4.60% calculated). Complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> does not show any weight loss up to 262<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, this is consistent with no lattice or coordinated water in the complex (see ).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The TGA diagrams show complexes 1-3 have similar thermal stabilities and behaviors in the range of 50-220°C. Complex 1 exhibits loss of one lattice water between 65 and 216°C (4.91% weight loss observed; 4.70% calculated), complex 2 exhibits loss of the water molecules between 48 and 147°C (4.05% weight loss observed; 4.28% calculated), while complex 3 exhibits loss of two water molecules between 66 and 195°C (4.53% weight loss observed; 4.60% calculated). Complex 4 does not show any weight loss up to 262°C, this is consistent with no lattice or coordinated water in the complex (see ).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Crystal structures</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the orthorhombic <ce:italic>Aba</ce:italic>2 space group, the absolute structure was determined from the Flack parameter, refined to be 0.01(3), indicating the complex is of correct absolute structure. X-ray structure analysis reveals that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a one-dimensional zigzag chain based on the [Ag(PyBIm)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O] unit (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>). The silver(I) atom is three coordinated, by one aqua ligand (Ag1–O1w 2.596(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and two PyBIm ligands via N<ce:inf loc="post">Py</ce:inf> and N<ce:inf loc="post">BIm</ce:inf> nitrogen donor atoms (Ag1–N1 2.222(3), Ag1–N2 2.172(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), exhibiting a distorted “T” shaped coordination (N1–Ag1–O1w 89.2(1)°, N2–Ag1–N1 151.3(1)°, N2–Ag1–O1w 114.5(1)°).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structures

Complex 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Aba2 space group, the absolute structure was determined from the Flack parameter, refined to be 0.01(3), indicating the complex is of correct absolute structure. X-ray structure analysis reveals that 1 is a one-dimensional zigzag chain based on the [Ag(PyBIm)⋅H2O] unit ( ). The silver(I) atom is three coordinated, by one aqua ligand (Ag1-O1w 2.596(3)Å) and two PyBIm ligands via NPy and NBIm nitrogen donor atoms (Ag1-N1 2.222(3), Ag1-N2 2.172(2)Å), exhibiting a distorted "T" shaped coordination (N1-Ag1-O1w 89.2(1)°, N2-Ag1-N1 151.3(1)°, N2-Ag1-O1w 114.5(1)°).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The benzimidazolyl rings are almost coplanar in the “zigzag” chain, and the pyridyl ring deviates from the benzimidazolyl ring of the same PyBIm ligand with a dihedral angle of 26.7°. The Ag(I) atoms are bridged by the PyBIm ligands with a separation of 7.111<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Strong hydrogen-bonding interactions between the N–H group of benzimidazolyl, lattice water and nitrate (N3⋯O1 2.901(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, O1w⋯O1 2.969(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, O1w⋯O2 2.850(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) as well as π–π (3.36<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) interactions connect the one-dimensional chains into a two-dimensional double-layer, and the double-layers are further connected into a three-dimensional framework through inter-molecular interactions (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>), the π–π interactions of the adjacent double-layer are rather weak, as the overlap of the aromatic rings can be neglected (more than 4.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The benzimidazolyl rings are almost coplanar in the "zigzag" chain, and the pyridyl ring deviates from the benzimidazolyl ring of the same PyBIm ligand with a dihedral angle of 26.7°. The Ag(I) atoms are bridged by the PyBIm ligands with a separation of 7.111Å. Strong hydrogen-bonding interactions between the N-H group of benzimidazolyl, lattice water and nitrate (N3⋯O1 2.901(4)Å, O1w⋯O1 2.969(4)Å, O1w⋯O2 2.850(5)Å) as well as π-π (3.36Å) interactions connect the one-dimensional chains into a two-dimensional double-layer, and the double-layers are further connected into a three-dimensional framework through inter-molecular interactions ( ), the π-π interactions of the adjacent double-layer are rather weak, as the overlap of the aromatic rings can be neglected (more than 4.5Å).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In the two-dimensional double-layer, interestingly, the one-dimensional “zigzag” chains are connected by the nitrate groups to the adjacent chains from the other layer through hydrogen-bonding as well as strong π–π interactions (3.36<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>). This two-dimensional double-layer is not like the common reported ones . In complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the one-dimensional “zigzag” chains are not directly connected into a two-dimensional sheet, but indirectly. To the best of our knowledge, this phenomenon has not been reported before.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the two-dimensional double-layer, interestingly, the one-dimensional "zigzag" chains are connected by the nitrate groups to the adjacent chains from the other layer through hydrogen-bonding as well as strong π-π interactions (3.36Å) ( ). This two-dimensional double-layer is not like the common reported ones . In complex 1, the one-dimensional "zigzag" chains are not directly connected into a two-dimensional sheet, but indirectly. To the best of our knowledge, this phenomenon has not been reported before.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">With regard to the influence of the N–H group of the PyBIm ligand, this structure is greatly different from the reported complex [Ag(2,4-bpy)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
, where the counter ion is weakly coordinated with the silver atom and leads to a two-dimensional sheet without hydrogen-bonding interactions. Although the coordination sphere is similar to that of [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(PyBIm)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O , due to the anion effect, great differences occur in the crystal packing.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: With regard to the influence of the N-H group of the PyBIm ligand, this structure is greatly different from the reported complex [Ag(2,4-bpy)]⋅NO3 , where the counter ion is weakly coordinated with the silver atom and leads to a two-dimensional sheet without hydrogen-bonding interactions. Although the coordination sphere is similar to that of [Ag2(PyBIm)2(H2O)2]SO4 ⋅H2O , due to the anion effect, great differences occur in the crystal packing.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in the orthorhombic <ce:italic>Pbcn</ce:italic> space group, the single-crystal X-ray structure analysis reveals that <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has the similar one-dimensional zigzag chain based on [Ag(PyBIm)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O] units, as in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Similar to complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the silver(I) atom is also three coordinated by one aqua ligand (Ag1–O1w 2.482(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and two PyBIm ligands via N<ce:inf loc="post">Py</ce:inf> and N<ce:inf loc="post">BIm</ce:inf> nitrogen donor atoms (Ag1–N1 2.198(2), Ag1–N2 2.152(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), exhibiting a distorted “T” shaped coordination geometry (N1–Ag1–O1w 90.2(8)°, N2–Ag1–N1 153.4(8)°, N2–Ag1–O1w 112.6(8)°) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Complex 2 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Pbcn space group, the single-crystal X-ray structure analysis reveals that 2 has the similar one-dimensional zigzag chain based on [Ag(PyBIm)⋅H2O] units, as in complex 1. Similar to complex 1, the silver(I) atom is also three coordinated by one aqua ligand (Ag1-O1w 2.482(2)Å) and two PyBIm ligands via NPy and NBIm nitrogen donor atoms (Ag1-N1 2.198(2), Ag1-N2 2.152(2)Å), exhibiting a distorted "T" shaped coordination geometry (N1-Ag1-O1w 90.2(8)°, N2-Ag1-N1 153.4(8)°, N2-Ag1-O1w 112.6(8)°) ( ).

elements.content:

elements.clean_text: Complex 3 consists of a one-dimensional double-chain ( ), each unit has two distinct silver atoms in the complex. Both of them are two coordinated and bridged by the PyBIm ligands via NPy and NBIm (Ag1-N1 2.178(4), Ag1-N2 2.135(4), Ag2-N4 2.193(4), Ag2-N5 2.155(3)Å) into two "zigzag" chains with adjacent intra-chain Ag⋯Ag separations of 7.443 and 7.542Å. The NPy-Ag-NBIm bond angles are slightly larger than those of complexes 1 and 2 (N1-Ag1-N2 157.8(2), N4-Ag1-N5 155.8(2)°), indicating stronger covalent interactions among the silver(I) and nitrogen atoms. The two distinct "zigzag" chains are connected by hydrogen-bonding (O1w⋯F3 3.019Å) as well as π-π interactions (3.35-3.40Å) into a double-chain, unlike the common reported molecular ladder or molecular railroad , the double-chain in complex 3 is not jointed by coordination bonds. Besides, O1w and F1 of [SiF6]2- are also weakly coordinated to the silver(I) atoms with a distance of about 2.610 and 2.605Å (Ag1⋯O1w 2.610, Ag2⋯F1 2.605Å), respectively. The Ag⋯F (2.605Å) distance is much shorter than other silver(I) complexes with the [SiF6]2- groups acting only as a counter ion (2.702Å) , but longer than the bonded Ag-F distance in the     BF   4     -     system (2.34-2.53Å) . The interaction between O1w and Ag1 is comparable to that found in silver(I) carboxylate and oxalate complexes (2.23-2.52 and 2.17-2.61Å), respectively , whilst it is greatly shorter than the sum of van der Waals radii (3.24Å) of the Ag(I) ion and oxygen atom . The hydrogen-bonding interactions between O1w and F3 (O1w⋯F3 3.019Å) also bring the double-chains into a two-dimensional sheet (see ), and these sheets are further aggregated into a three-dimensional framework through strong π-π interactions, with the lattice water and     SiF   6     2 -     groups acting as guest molecules . Interestingly, the     SiF   6     2 -     groups are connected by the lattice water molecules (O2w) through hydrogen-bonding (O2w⋯F3 2.708, O2w⋯F5 2.894Å) interactions into a one-dimensional chain in the channel (see ).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is attributed with a two-dimensional network. Unlike the former complexes, the silver(I) atom is four coordinated (Ag1–N1 2.195(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Ag1–N2 2.188(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Ag1–O1 2.571(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Ag1–O3 2.597(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), exhibiting a distorted tetrahedral coordination sphere (N2–Ag1–N1 149.8(6)°, N2–Ag1–O1 113.1(6)°, N1–Ag1–O1 91.1(6)°, N2–Ag1–O3 89.4(6)°, N1–Ag1–O3 115.3(6)°, O1–Ag1–O3 74.6(5)°) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>). The silver(I) atom deviates from the basic plane formed by N2, N1a and O3a less than 0.0991<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The Ag–O bond lengths (2.571(2) and 2.597(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively) are slightly shorter than that in complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (Ag1–O1w 2.610<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), which is in the normal range for Ag–O bond distances for silver carboxylate and oxalate complexes . The O2 atom of the 1,3-BDC ligand is protoned, C13–O2 (1.297(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) is longer than C13–O1 (1.223(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), and forms hydrogen-bonding interactions with the O3 atom (O2⋯O3 2.450(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) of the adjacent HBDC<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand. The silver(I) atoms are bridged by PyBIm into the similar “zigzag” [Ag(PyBIm)]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> chain as complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, and the chains are further connected by the bridging HBDC<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand into a two-dimensional sheet (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig7"></ce:float-anchor>). The hydrogen-bonding (O2⋯O3 2.450(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) as well as π–π interactions aggregate the undulating sheets into a three-dimensional framework.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that complex 4 is attributed with a two-dimensional network. Unlike the former complexes, the silver(I) atom is four coordinated (Ag1-N1 2.195(2)Å, Ag1-N2 2.188(2)Å, Ag1-O1 2.571(2)Å, Ag1-O3 2.597(2)Å), exhibiting a distorted tetrahedral coordination sphere (N2-Ag1-N1 149.8(6)°, N2-Ag1-O1 113.1(6)°, N1-Ag1-O1 91.1(6)°, N2-Ag1-O3 89.4(6)°, N1-Ag1-O3 115.3(6)°, O1-Ag1-O3 74.6(5)°) ( ). The silver(I) atom deviates from the basic plane formed by N2, N1a and O3a less than 0.0991Å. The Ag-O bond lengths (2.571(2) and 2.597(2)Å, respectively) are slightly shorter than that in complex 3 (Ag1-O1w 2.610Å), which is in the normal range for Ag-O bond distances for silver carboxylate and oxalate complexes . The O2 atom of the 1,3-BDC ligand is protoned, C13-O2 (1.297(3)Å) is longer than C13-O1 (1.223(3)Å), and forms hydrogen-bonding interactions with the O3 atom (O2⋯O3 2.450(2)Å) of the adjacent HBDC- ligand. The silver(I) atoms are bridged by PyBIm into the similar "zigzag" [Ag(PyBIm)]∞ chain as complexes 1-3, and the chains are further connected by the bridging HBDC- ligand into a two-dimensional sheet ( ). The hydrogen-bonding (O2⋯O3 2.450(2)Å) as well as π-π interactions aggregate the undulating sheets into a three-dimensional framework.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The coordination mode of the HBD<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand is greatly different from the reported silver(I) complexes based on benzenecarboxylate derivatives, where the adoption of a bidentate mode for the carboxylate group is very common, leading to weak ligand unsupported Ag⋯Ag interactions . In complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, either the carboxylate or carboxylic group demonstrates a unidentate bonding fashion.</ce:para>

In complex 4, either the carboxylate or carboxylic group demonstrates a unidentate bonding fashion.

elements.clean_text:
Anion exchange properties of complexes 2 and 3 

The     ClO   4     -     anion does not coordinate to silver(I) in complex 2, while the F- of     SiF   6     2 -     weakly coordinates to the Ag(I) atom in complex 3, both anions are only loosely bound to the framework through the hydrogen bonds. To investigate whether these loosely bound     ClO   4     -     and     SiF   6     2 -     anions can be exchanged by other anions, anion exchange reactions were carried out for complexes 2 and 3. Well-ground powers of complexes 2 and 3 (50mg) were suspended in aqueous solution (10ml) of NaBF4 and Na2SO4 (1g), respectively. These mixtures were stirred for one day at room temperature, then filtered, washed with water and dried under vacuum to give a white powder. This procedure was repeated at least three times. The element analyses reveal nearly 100% exchange for both complexes 2 and 3, the exchanged products gave sharp XPRD patterns, which are similar to that of complexes 2 and 3, respectively. Indicating the crystal structures have been maintained in both complexes (see ). This phenomenon is similar to the anion properties of cage-like frameworks and cation-layered architectures .

elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The PyBIm ligand acts as a bridging ligand rather than a terminal one  in the four silver(I) complexes, and bridges the Ag(I) atoms into similar "zigzag" chains, in which the coordination number of the silver(I) atom varies from two to four. Due to the influence of anion symmetry , a great difference in crystal packing is demonstrated. For instance,     NO   3     -     (D 3h ) forms hydrogen-bonding interactions greatly different from that of     ClO   4     -     (D 4h ) and SiF6 (D 6h ), resulting in a double-layer, a three-dimensional framework and a novel double-chain structure, respectively. The HBDC- anions act not only as counter ions but also as bridging ligands, leading to the formation of a two-dimensional coordinate sheet. Although the N-H groups of the PyBIm ligands do not coordinate to silver(I) atoms, they form strong hydrogen-bonding interactions with the lattice water and anionic counter ions, leading to a great influence on the crystal packing.

Synthesis of [Ag(PyBIm) ⋅ H  2  O] ⋅ NO  3  (  1  ). An acetonitrile (5mL) solution of AgNO3 (0.085g, 0.50mmol) was slowly diffused into an ethanol (5mL) solution of PyBIm (0.097g, 0.50mmol). Colorless crystals formed in about two weeks (80% yield) Anal. Calc. for C12H11AgN4O4: C, 37.62; H, 2.89; N, 14.62. Found: C, 37.15; H, 3.12; N, 14.13%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3434s, 1613s, 1559w, 1537w, 1495m, 1480w, 1443, 1414, 1385s, 1357s, 1229m, 1072m, 1041m, 1017w, 838m, 821m, 782s, 700m, 556m, 502w.

 Synthesis of [Ag(PyBIm) ⋅ H  2  O] ⋅ ClO  4  (  2  ). An ethanol solution (5mL) of AgClO4 (0.06g, 0.30mmol) was slowly diffused into an ethanol solution of PyBIm (0.06g, 0.30mmol). Colorless crystals formed in about three weeks (75% yield). Anal. Calc. for C12H11AgClN3O5: C, 34.27; H, 2.64; N, 9.99. Found: C, 34.15; H, 3.12; N, 10.13%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3496s, 1612s, 1537w, 1494m, 1481w, 1436s, 1319m, 1285w, 1226m, 1120vs, 1085vs, 969w, 932w, 838m, 816m, 775s, 744w, 672w, 624s, 557w, 500w.

 Synthesis of [Ag  2  (PyBIm)  2  ] ⋅ (SiF  6  ) ⋅ 2H  2  O (  3  ). A solution of Ag2SiF6 (0.22g, 0.61mmol), PyBIm (0.24g, 1.22mmol), NaF (0.025g, 0.61mmol) and H2O (15ml) was stirred under ambient conditions, then sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, heated at 150°C for 5 days and cooled to room temperature. The resulting product was recovered by filtration, washed with distilled water and dried in air (65% yield). Anal. Calc. for C24H22Ag2F6N6O2Si: C, 36.75; H, 2.83; N, 10.72. Found: C, 36.54; H, 3.09; N, 10.79%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3445s, 1614s, 1560w, 1541m, 1496w, 1481w, 1439s, 1384w, 1319m, 1287w, 1227m, 1118s, 1084s, 1065s, 1022s, 839m, 818m, 775s, 745s, 558m, 500w, 473m.

 Synthesis of [Ag(PyBIm)(HBDC)] (  4  ). A solution of Ag2O (0.069g, 0.30mmol), PyBIm (0.24g, 1.22mmol), H2BDC (0.101g, 0.61mmol) and H2O (15ml) was stirred under ambient conditions, then sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, heated at 150°C for 5 days and cooled to room temperature. The resulting product was recovered by filtration, washed with distilled water and dried in air (60% yield). Anal. Calc. for C20H14AgN3O4: C, 51.31; H, 3.01; N, 8.97. Found: C, 51.52; H, 3.26; N, 9.06%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3433s, 1416s, 1566m, 1778w, 1438m, 1384s, 1319m, 1283w, 1228w, 1095w, 1069m, 936m, 839m, 751s, 687m, 539w, 507w.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The TGA diagrams show complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> have similar thermal stabilities and behaviors in the range of 50–220<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits loss of one lattice water between 65 and 216<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (4.91% weight loss observed; 4.70% calculated), complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits loss of the water molecules between 48 and 147<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (4.05% weight loss observed; 4.28% calculated), while complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibits loss of two water molecules between 66 and 195<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (4.53% weight loss observed; 4.60% calculated). Complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> does not show any weight loss up to 262<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, this is consistent with no lattice or coordinated water in the complex (see ).</ce:para><ce:para view="all">Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> consists of a one-dimensional double-chain (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>), each unit has two distinct silver atoms in the complex. Both of them are two coordinated and bridged by the PyBIm ligands via N<ce:inf loc="post">Py</ce:inf> and N<ce:inf loc="post">BIm</ce:inf> (Ag1–N1 2.178(4), Ag1–N2 2.135(4), Ag2–N4 2.193(4), Ag2–N5 2.155(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) into two “zigzag” chains with adjacent intra-chain Ag⋯Ag separations of 7.443 and 7.542<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The N<ce:inf loc="post">Py</ce:inf>–Ag–N<ce:inf loc="post">BIm</ce:inf> bond angles are slightly larger than those of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (N1–Ag1–N2 157.8(2), N4–Ag1–N5 155.8(2)°), indicating stronger covalent interactions among the silver(I) and nitrogen atoms. The two distinct “zigzag” chains are connected by hydrogen-bonding (O1w⋯F3 3.019<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) as well as π–π interactions (3.35–3.40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) into a double-chain, unlike the common reported molecular ladder or molecular railroad , the double-chain in complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is not jointed by coordination bonds. Besides, O1w and F1 of [SiF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> are also weakly coordinated to the silver(I) atoms with a distance of about 2.610 and 2.605<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (Ag1⋯O1w 2.610, Ag2⋯F1 2.605<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), respectively. The Ag⋯F (2.605<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) distance is much shorter than other silver(I) complexes with the [SiF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> groups acting only as a counter ion (2.702<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) , but longer than the bonded Ag–F distance in the <mml:math altimg="si4.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mmultiscripts>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mtext>BF</mml:mtext>
</mml:mrow>
<mml:mrow>

</mml:mrow>

<mml:mrow>

</mml:mrow>
</mml:mmultiscripts>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math> system (2.34–2.53<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) . The interaction between O1w and Ag1 is comparable to that found in silver(I) carboxylate and oxalate complexes (2.23–2.52 and 2.17–2.61<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), respectively , whilst it is greatly shorter than the sum of van der Waals radii (3.24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) of the Ag(I) ion and oxygen atom . The hydrogen-bonding interactions between O1w and F3 (O1w⋯F3 3.019<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) also bring the double-chains into a two-dimensional sheet (see ), and these sheets are further aggregated into a three-dimensional framework through strong π–π interactions, with the lattice water and <mml:math altimg="si5.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>

<mml:mo>-</mml:mo>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:mmultiscripts>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math> groups acting as guest molecules . Interestingly, the <mml:math altimg="si6.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mmultiscripts>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mtext>SiF</mml:mtext>
</mml:mrow>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mn>6</mml:mn>
</mml:mrow>

<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>
<mml:mo>-</mml:mo>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:mmultiscripts>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math> groups are connected by the lattice water molecules (O2w) through hydrogen-bonding (O2w⋯F3 2.708, O2w⋯F5 2.894<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) interactions into a one-dimensional chain in the channel (see ).</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is attributed with a two-dimensional network. Unlike the former complexes, the silver(I) atom is four coordinated (Ag1–N1 2.195(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Ag1–N2 2.188(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Ag1–O1 2.571(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Ag1–O3 2.597(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), exhibiting a distorted tetrahedral coordination sphere (N2–Ag1–N1 149.8(6)°, N2–Ag1–O1 113.1(6)°, N1–Ag1–O1 91.1(6)°, N2–Ag1–O3 89.4(6)°, N1–Ag1–O3 115.3(6)°, O1–Ag1–O3 74.6(5)°) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>). The silver(I) atom deviates from the basic plane formed by N2, N1a and O3a less than 0.0991<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The Ag–O bond lengths (2.571(2) and 2.597(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively) are slightly shorter than that in complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (Ag1–O1w 2.610<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), which is in the normal range for Ag–O bond distances for silver carboxylate and oxalate complexes . The O2 atom of the 1,3-BDC ligand is protoned, C13–O2 (1.297(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) is longer than C13–O1 (1.223(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), and forms hydrogen-bonding interactions with the O3 atom (O2⋯O3 2.450(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) of the adjacent HBDC<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand. The silver(I) atoms are bridged by PyBIm into the similar “zigzag” [Ag(PyBIm)]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> chain as complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, and the chains are further connected by the bridging HBDC<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand into a two-dimensional sheet (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig7"></ce:float-anchor>). The hydrogen-bonding (O2⋯O3 2.450(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) as well as π–π interactions aggregate the undulating sheets into a three-dimensional framework.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Anion exchange properties of complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The <mml:math altimg="si7.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mmultiscripts>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mtext>ClO</mml:mtext>

</mml:mrow>
</mml:mmultiscripts>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math> anion does not coordinate to silver(I) in complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, while the F<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> of <mml:math altimg="si8.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mmultiscripts>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mtext>SiF</mml:mtext>
</mml:mrow>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mn>6</mml:mn>
</mml:mrow>
<mml:none></mml:none>
<mml:none></mml:none>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>
<mml:mo>-</mml:mo>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:mmultiscripts>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math> weakly coordinates to the Ag(I) atom in complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, both anions are only loosely bound to the framework through the hydrogen bonds. To investigate whether these loosely bound <mml:math altimg="si9.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>

cln_elements.clean_text:
The TGA diagrams show complexes 1-3 have similar thermal stabilities and behaviors in the range of 50-220°C. Complex 1 exhibits loss of one lattice water between 65 and 216°C (4.91% weight loss observed; 4.70% calculated), complex 2 exhibits loss of the water molecules between 48 and 147°C (4.05% weight loss observed; 4.28% calculated), while complex 3 exhibits loss of two water molecules between 66 and 195°C (4.53% weight loss observed; 4.60% calculated). Complex 4 does not show any weight loss up to 262°C, this is consistent with no lattice or coordinated water in the complex (see ).

Complex 3 consists of a one-dimensional double-chain ( ), each unit has two distinct silver atoms in the complex. Both of them are two coordinated and bridged by the PyBIm ligands via NPy and NBIm (Ag1-N1 2.178(4), Ag1-N2 2.135(4), Ag2-N4 2.193(4), Ag2-N5 2.155(3)Å) into two "zigzag" chains with adjacent intra-chain Ag⋯Ag separations of 7.443 and 7.542Å. The NPy-Ag-NBIm bond angles are slightly larger than those of complexes 1 and 2 (N1-Ag1-N2 157.8(2), N4-Ag1-N5 155.8(2)°), indicating stronger covalent interactions among the silver(I) and nitrogen atoms. The two distinct "zigzag" chains are connected by hydrogen-bonding (O1w⋯F3 3.019Å) as well as π-π interactions (3.35-3.40Å) into a double-chain, unlike the common reported molecular ladder or molecular railroad , the double-chain in complex 3 is not jointed by coordination bonds. Besides, O1w and F1 of [SiF6]2- are also weakly coordinated to the silver(I) atoms with a distance of about 2.610 and 2.605Å (Ag1⋯O1w 2.610, Ag2⋯F1 2.605Å), respectively. The Ag⋯F (2.605Å) distance is much shorter than other silver(I) complexes with the [SiF6]2- groups acting only as a counter ion (2.702Å) , but longer than the bonded Ag-F distance in the     BF   4     -     system (2.34-2.53Å) . The interaction between O1w and Ag1 is comparable to that found in silver(I) carboxylate and oxalate complexes (2.23-2.52 and 2.17-2.61Å), respectively , whilst it is greatly shorter than the sum of van der Waals radii (3.24Å) of the Ag(I) ion and oxygen atom . The hydrogen-bonding interactions between O1w and F3 (O1w⋯F3 3.019Å) also bring the double-chains into a two-dimensional sheet (see ), and these sheets are further aggregated into a three-dimensional framework through strong π-π interactions, with the lattice water and     SiF   6     2 -     groups acting as guest molecules . Interestingly, the     SiF   6     2 -     groups are connected by the lattice water molecules (O2w) through hydrogen-bonding (O2w⋯F3 2.708, O2w⋯F5 2.894Å) interactions into a one-dimensional chain in the channel (see ).

The single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that complex 4 is attributed with a two-dimensional network. Unlike the former complexes, the silver(I) atom is four coordinated (Ag1-N1 2.195(2)Å, Ag1-N2 2.188(2)Å, Ag1-O1 2.571(2)Å, Ag1-O3 2.597(2)Å), exhibiting a distorted tetrahedral coordination sphere (N2-Ag1-N1 149.8(6)°, N2-Ag1-O1 113.1(6)°, N1-Ag1-O1 91.1(6)°, N2-Ag1-O3 89.4(6)°, N1-Ag1-O3 115.3(6)°, O1-Ag1-O3 74.6(5)°) ( ). The silver(I) atom deviates from the basic plane formed by N2, N1a and O3a less than 0.0991Å. The Ag-O bond lengths (2.571(2) and 2.597(2)Å, respectively) are slightly shorter than that in complex 3 (Ag1-O1w 2.610Å), which is in the normal range for Ag-O bond distances for silver carboxylate and oxalate complexes . The O2 atom of the 1,3-BDC ligand is protoned, C13-O2 (1.297(3)Å) is longer than C13-O1 (1.223(3)Å), and forms hydrogen-bonding interactions with the O3 atom (O2⋯O3 2.450(2)Å) of the adjacent HBDC- ligand. The silver(I) atoms are bridged by PyBIm into the similar "zigzag" [Ag(PyBIm)]∞ chain as complexes 1-3, and the chains are further connected by the bridging HBDC- ligand into a two-dimensional sheet ( ). The hydrogen-bonding (O2⋯O3 2.450(2)Å) as well as π-π interactions aggregate the undulating sheets into a three-dimensional framework.

Anion exchange properties of complexes 2 and 3 

The     ClO   4     -     anion does not coordinate to silver(I) in complex 2, while the F- of     SiF   6     2 -     weakly coordinates to the Ag(I) atom in complex 3, both anions are only loosely bound to the framework through the hydrogen bonds. To investigate whether these loosely bound     ClO   4     -     and     SiF   6     2 -     anions can be exchanged by other anions, anion exchange reactions were carried out for complexes 2 and 3. Well-ground powers of complexes 2 and 3 (50mg) were suspended in aqueous solution (10ml) of NaBF4 and Na2SO4 (1g), respectively. These mixtures were stirred for one day at room temperature, then filtered, washed with water and dried under vacuum to give a white powder. This procedure was repeated at least three times. The element analyses reveal nearly 100% exchange for both complexes 2 and 3, the exchanged products gave sharp XPRD patterns, which are similar to that of complexes 2 and 3, respectively. Indicating the crystal structures have been maintained in both complexes (see ). This phenomenon is similar to the anion properties of cage-like frameworks and cation-layered architectures .
